intro: Selinum copticum, commonly known as the Egyptian cumin, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes parsley, carrots, and dill. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in umbels, and its seeds are used as a spice. The leaves are aromatic and have a slightly bitter taste. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a hardy perennial in suitable climates.
